info.game_comments:
Jason Keller game 1.
Alex acknowledges a 102-year-old woman (and Jeopardy! fan) in the audience.

(1, 1).clue: A new rule in this Yahoo sports fantasy game is the Mulligan, which allows you to drop your worst weekly score

(3, 1).clue: Toronto-born Robbie Robertson was part of the Bob Dylan backup group that made it big on their own using this name

(4, 1).clue: Maybe they take tokens at this chain that offers Italian B.M.T. & Black Forest ham sandwiches

(5, 1).clue: He was the youngest man elected president &, sadly, the youngest to die in office

(6, 1).clue: It's defined as a voice extending above a man or woman's normal range

(1, 2).clue: Jimi Hendrix fans know kissthisguy.com is always good for a laugh, as it's an "archive of misheard" these

(3, 2).clue: He recorded some of his biggest albums, including "Rust Never Sleeps", backed up by Crazy Horse

(4, 2).clue: In the world according to this fish, the kind made into gefilte fish is called the German or Israeli type

(5, 2).clue: His home at 19 North Square is the oldest building in downtown Boston

(6, 2).clue: a single unit of a General Mills cereal, or a British expression meaning "see you around, old chap"

(1, 3).clue: This website named for a curious mythological gal hosts the Music Genome Project for your listening pleasure

(3, 3).clue: We can ask about Montreal's Men Without Hats if we want to (if we don't, nobody will); in 1983 they hit No. 3 with this

(4, 3).clue: Leave the gun; take this Italian treat of pastry shells stuffed with a sweetened filling of whipped ricotta

(5, 3).clue: He's the botanist seen here in 1940

(6, 3).clue: It's the Japanese game seen here

(1, 4).clue: Press "Scan" on the social site that bills itself as "Chat" this game & you are visually connected to a random user

(3, 4).clue: In 2007 this Montreal group was "aflame" with creativity on their album "Neon Bible"

(4, 4).clue: Mock this soup is sometimes garnished with calves' brains; who can say no to that?

(5, 4).clue: One of Washington, D.C.'s major airports is named for this Secretary of State

(6, 4).clue: A type of con game; many a police department used to have a squad named for it

(1, 5).clue: Established in 2007, this microblogging site that sounds like an acrobat handles 40 million posts a day

(3, 5).clue: This arena-rock trio hit it big in the '70s with the Ayn Rand-inspired album "2112"

(4, 5).clue: This name for the "food of the gods" now means a dessert of chilled fruit mixed with coconut

(5, 5).clue: After starring in "A Man for All Seasons" in London & on Broadway, he won an Oscar for the movie

(6, 5).clue: This word for a devotee of an activity is Spanish for "enthusiast"

(1, 1).clue: "Okay, I did have my mom killed in 59 A.D. & wife no. 1 in 62, but I've been a good boy (& emperor!).  I'd like a fiddle. Now!"

(2, 1).clue: On August 5, 1884 the cornerstone for its pedestal was laid on Bedloe's Island

(3, 1).clue: This alternate name for the kneecap is from the Latin for "little plate"

(5, 1).clue: Meryl Streep was nominated but didn't have the recipe for a 2009 Oscar when she played Ms. Child in this film

(6, 1).clue: The cape-wearing artiste who settled in the village was just one of these "in a round hole"

(1, 2).clue: "Next year, in 1799, I want to stage the coup d'etat of 18th Brumaire & become first consul.  I'll want a lot more after that"

(2, 2).clue: Serving from 1941 to 1946, Harlan Stone was the 12th guy to head up this important group

(3, 2).clue: Italian anatomist Alfonso Corti gave his name to the organ of Corti, which is the actual organ of this sense

(6, 2).clue: Want conversation?  At the barbershop you'll find someone ready to sit around & "chew" this

(1, 3).clue: "...& one last thing.  If a Spaniard ever topples my rule as the 9th Aztec emperor, I'd like but one thing...revenge!"

(2, 3).clue: According to 17th century poet Richard Lovelace, "stone walls do not" one of these "make"

(3, 3).clue: This scientific name for the tailbone comes from its resemblance to a cuckoo bird's beak

(6, 3).clue: Attempts to get money from the mill owner are in vain; "you can't get" this "out of a stone"

(1, 4).clue: "If Edward IV dies in 1483, I want in as Lord Protector & eventually, king.  & a horse!  That's super important!"

(2, 4).clue: Geologists use these 2 Greek-derived terms to describe the "New Stone Age" & the "Old Stone Age" time periods

(3, 4).clue: This tough membrane that forms the outermost covering of the brain is Latin for "hard mother"

(5, 4).clue: For a SAG award, Susan Sarandon's "Dead Man Walking" work beat Meryl's romance with Clint in this 1995 film

(6, 4).clue: Like a Tower of London guard, Ed has done this type of "service", running our volunteer fire department

(1, 5).clue: "I built the temples of Abu Simbel, but what I'd like is to outlive my first dozen heirs & be preserved in a Cairo museum"

(2, 5).clue: From about 1,200 to 400 B.C., these people carved stone heads, like the one seen here, & lived along the Gulf of Mexico

(3, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew shows an anatomical animation on the monitor.)  The hyoid bone, which supports the tongue, takes its name from the Greek word hyoeides, meaning shaped like the lowercase form of this Greek letter

(4, 5).clue: Baku, Azerbaijan (a salt lake that's called a sea)

(5, 5).clue: The Golden Globes nominated Meryl for this 2004 remake about a brainwashed assassin, but she got shot down

(6, 5).clue: The village undertaker literally "knows" this phrase, but Mrs. Smith the postmistress knows too

(0, 0).clue: A Roman legal term for a debtor sentenced to servitude is the origin of this term for a slave to a vice
